answers.answer: If you had a thyroid condition either or both doctors would have called and you would have gotten in to seem them, believe me.  Your levels are fine. Even within the normal levels that you quoted, which is a target level for those already diagnosed and treated and not meant as a diagnose level, which is quite a bit higher (OR LOWER).Antibodies are not curable or treatable, nothing can be done about them. Its the thyroid that is treated from the damages of the antibodies.  Antibodies are present in a high proportion of people with chronic thyroiditis, are also present in lesser numbers of people with other thyroid diseases, other autoimmune disorders such as Sjögren syndrome, lupus, rheumatoid arthritis,  pernicious anemia and people that show no evidence of disease. So therefore, thyroid levels are the prevailing diagnose for thyroid, not antibodies.It might be the diabetes causing some or most or all your issues.  My husband was diabetic and he had periodic hair loss and dry skin.

Thanks GravesLady!  It takes a load off my mind.  It's hard enough dealing with the type 1 diabetes and to not have to worry about thyroid on top of it.  Someone suggested to me that the antibodies might be triggered an allergic reaction to something.  Does anyone have experience with figuring out what can trigger an autoimmune attack?Best,Wendy

Stress -  mental, physical and environmental triggers immune/autoimmune and health in general, even weight. But specific autoimmune is in the genes brought to the surface through the stress factor via the immune system.
You are AWESOME.  You've done a great deed today by relieving my mind.Now to find ways to deal with stress....Actually I've made a lot of progress on that in the past few months...Thanks,Wendy

question: Hi,Please help me interpret these numbers and help me to know what my next step is.I had a thyroid antibody test and it came back at 110.  I hear that normal is 0-3.9 so this seems off-scale. My T4 was 0.9 and TSH was 1.96.  I have recently had dry skin, hair falling out and puffy eyes.   I've found it hard to lose weight for years, although appearance of  Type 1 diabetes made me lose 12 pounds.  Energy is not great but okay.  Periods are extra-light, extra-long and closer together (23 days) as of late.I can't get another appointment with any endocrinologist in my area.  (They're booked for months and by doctor doesn't seem to return phone calls).  Could someone please help me know what to do rather than have me stew for six months before I can see my doctor?I'm 41 years old, female (obviously), recently diagnosed (two weeks ago) Type 1 diabetic with GAD65 antibodies of 14.  Otherwise good health.  I take 6 U Lantus/day plus an occasional bolus of 1-2 U Novolg for meals that might have carbs.  I am normal weight (142 lbs, 5' 7") and I exercise every day and I try to eat low-carb.Thank you so much!Wendy
title: results of Thyroid antibody test
